item.title: An Unlikely Source of Crypto Innovation: Afghanistan
item.description: The repressive Taliban government is suspicious of the internet. But a start-up in the country is building blockchain-based tools to transform humanitarian aid.
item.dc:creator: Aryn Baker and Emile Ducke
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Local beneficiaries wait in line to receive their aid payments as part of a Mercy Corps pilot project using HesabPay, a blockchain-based payment system developed in Afghanistan, in the town of Halfaya, Syria.

item.title: What Europe Learned From the Greenland Crisis
item.description: Territorial integrity is a core tenet of Europe that is at risk from Russian and American imperialism. Brussels has fought back.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Juliette Pavy for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest against President Trump’s attempt to take over Greenland, in Nuuk, last week.

item.title: As Iran Grieves, Accounts Emerge of Disrespectful Treatment of Protest Victims
item.description: Witness testimony and videos from Tehran’s largest cemetery show disrespectful treatment of the dead after a brutal government crackdown.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Kiana Hayeri
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: An image taken from a video posted on social media and verified by The New York Times, showing a scene at the Behesht-e Zahra cemetery in Tehran.

item.title: Ukrainian, Russian and U.S. Officials Meet in Abu Dhabi for Peace Talks
item.description: In the past, Ukrainian and Russian negotiators have relied on Americans to mediate, and it was unclear how the talks would play out.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier from the 63rd Mechanized Brigade firing a howitzer at a Russian position in eastern Ukraine this month.

item.title: Peru’s President May Be Ousted Over Secret Meetings with Chinese Businessmen
item.description: Leaked videos have prompted a scandal involving President José Jerí and two Chinese men under investigation.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak and Mitra Taj
item.media:description: President José Jerí of Peru arrives at Congress to speak to lawmakers in Lima, Peru, on Wednesday amid a scandal over undisclosed meetings with a Chinese businessman.

item.title: Trump Says U.S. ‘Armada’ Is Heading to Iran, Raising Pressure on Regime
item.description: President Trump said the United States was “watching Iran” and sending a naval force there, despite also saying that his threats had halted executions.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Trump spoke to reporters on Air Force One as he flew back to Washington from Davos, Switzerland, on Thursday.

item.title: No Beer for You: How British Pubs Fought a Tax Increase
item.description: More than 1,400 pubs declared a ban on Labour lawmakers in response to a plan to raise business rates significantly. The move got attention, and results.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Andrew Testa
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Landlord Andy Lennox at his pub, The Old Thatch, earlier this month.

item.title: Ryan Wedding, Canadian Ex-Snowboarder Accused of Running Drug Ring, Is Arrested
item.description: Ryan Wedding, 44, who competed in snowboarding in the 2002 Winter Olympics, has been charged with murder and smuggling cocaine into the United States.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Ryan Wedding, a former Olympic snowboarder, has been charged with smuggling cocaine into the United States and with murder.

item.title: Trump Wants to Build More U.S. Military Bases in Greenland. How Many Are There Now?
item.description: The U.S. once maintained more than a dozen. Now it has one. President Trump wants more.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Jeffrey Gettleman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Thomas Traasdahl/Ritzau Scanpix, via Agence France-Presse – Getty Images
item.media:description: At the Pituffik Space Base in Greenland, the United States has 150 people who run missile defense and space surveillance.

item.title: Vietnam’s Leader Consolidates Power, Pledging ‘New Era of Prosperity’
item.description: To Lam, the head of Vietnam’s Communist Party, will also become president of the nation. His new stature comes with new risks.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave and Tung Ngo
item.media:credit: Linh Pham for The New York Times
item.media:description: To Lam, chief of Vietnam’s Communist Party, in the country’s capital, Hanoi, on Friday. His supercharged elevation upsets Vietnam’s traditional sharing of authority among four leaders.

item.title: What Happened At the Funeral For Fashion Designer Valentino
item.description: The designer Valentino Garavani, who died on Monday at 93, was celebrated in Rome, a city that he “embodied,” according to its mayor.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: The coffin of the fashion designer Valentino Garavani arriving at his funeral in Rome on Friday.

item.title: Prosecutors in Spain End Investigation Into Julio Iglesias
item.description: Two women accused the singer, 82, of abusing them in the Caribbean and filed a complaint in Spain, but Spanish officials said that they did not have jurisdiction over the claim.
item.dc:creator: José Bautista
item.media:description: Julio Iglesias performing in 2014.

item.title: After Trump’s Ultimatum, Greenland Talks Include Sovereign U.S. Bases and No Drilling for Russia
item.description: Negotiators have discussed proposals to check Russian and Chinese influence in the Arctic and transfer sovereignty over pockets of Greenlandic land to the United States, an idea opposed by Denmark.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley, Lara Jakes and Adam Goldman
item.media:credit: Esther Horvath for The New York Times
item.media:description: Icebergs in Scoresby Sound in Greenland. In a speech at Davos, Switzerland, on Wednesday, President Trump ruled out using military force to take the island.

item.title: Filipino Journalist Gets Prison in Case Seen as Attack on Free Press
item.description: Frenchie Mae Cumpio and her former roommate were convicted of financing terrorism and sentenced to up to 18 years in prison.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez
item.media:credit: Jam Sta Rosa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Frenchie Mae Cumpio, right, and her former roommate Marielle Domequil arriving at Tacloban Regional Trial Court on Leyte island, in the Philippines, on Thursday.

item.title: U.S. Lays Out a Glittering Plan for Gaza, Including Skyscrapers
item.description: Jared Kushner, President Trump’s son-in-law, offered the proposal at a Davos ceremony to inaugurate the president’s “Board of Peace.”
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: President Trump with other world leaders at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Thursday.

item.title: Russia Jails U.S. Navy Veteran for Five Years
item.description: Charles Wayne Zimmerman, who had been fulfilling his dream to sail around the world, appears to be the latest American imprisoned as part of Russia’s “hostage diplomacy.”
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: Steve Witkoff, the presidential envoy who has been negotiating with the Kremlin on a peace deal in the Ukraine war, was believed to have raised the issue of incarcerated Americans during his repeated visits to Moscow.

item.title: Joint Chiefs Chairman Issues Rare Invitation to Foreign Military Heads
item.description: Top military leaders from 34 countries plan to discuss improving efforts in the Western Hemisphere to fight drug trafficking and transnational criminal organizations.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gen. Dan Caine’s meeting comes at a fraught time for Washington’s relations with its immediate neighbors as well as allies in Europe.

item.title: Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen of Denmark Visits Greenland
item.description: The trip by Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen to the Danish territory came amid pressure from President Trump and appeared to have been meant as reassurance to Greenlanders.
item.dc:creator: Maya Tekeli
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen of Denmark, in the tan coat; the mayor of Nuuk, Greenland, Avaaraq Olsenand; and Prime Minister Jens-Frederik Nielsen of Greenland set off on a highly choreographed walk through the city on Friday.

item.title: Under Pressure from Trump, Venezuela Agrees to Accept More U.S. Deportation Flights
item.description: Venezuela’s interim government, in another sign of its willingness to placate the Trump administration, is receiving more deportation flights. Three flights arrived this week.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal, Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: A deportation flight from the United States arriving at Simón Bolívar International Airport in Venezuela on Thursday.

item.title: Trump’s Turnabout on Greenland Shows the Limits of His Coercive Powers
item.description: President Trump’s faith in his ability to wring concessions by taking maximalist positions was on full display this week. So were the costs, as he splintered NATO and then undercut his credibility by climbing down from his threats.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Donald J. Trump on Air Force One en route to Washington on Thursday night.

item.title: Court Dismisses Bid to Prevent Auction of Nelson Mandela Memorabilia
item.description: The anti-apartheid leader’s eldest daughter won the right to sell some of his personal items after a two-year legal battle.
item.dc:creator: Zimasa Matiwane
item.media:description: Shirts that had belonged to Nelson Mandela at an auction in New York City in 2021. Guernsey’s in New York scheduled a separate online auction in 2024 that received widespread criticism in South Africa.

item.title: Trump’s Push to Take Greenland Holds Promise and Peril for Putin
item.description: If the United States under President Trump starts acting as if it’s Russia, where does that leave President Vladimir V. Putin?
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:description: President Trump with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Anchorage, in August.

item.title: For Greenland Tourism, Trump’s Interest Creates Uncertainty
item.description: Bookings to the island increased last year, and there are plans for two new airports. Threats from President Trump may change that.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Abend
item.media:description: Tourism in Greenland, a semiautonomous territory of the Kingdom of Denmark, has been rising steadily for years. Now some in the tourism industry are worried that recent geopolitical attention will have a negative impact.

item.title: U.K.’s Starmer Calls Trump’s Claims About NATO Soldiers in Afghanistan ‘Appalling’
item.description: President Trump said that NATO soldiers stayed “a little off the front lines” during the conflict. In Britain, which lost 457 soldiers in the war, the response was swift.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Joao Silva for The New York Times
item.media:description: British soldiers in Helmand Province, Afghanistan, in 2007. Britain lost 457 soldiers during two decades of fighting in Afghanistan.

item.title: What’s It Like to Climb a Skyscraper?
item.description: Few climbers take on this niche pursuit, where one mistake could mean death. Three of them talk about its unique mental and physical demands.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Alain Robert, known as the “French Spider-Man,” climbing the Burj Khalifa in Dubai, the tallest building in the world, in 2011.

item.title: Nazis, Soviets and Trump: America’s Fixation With Greenland
item.description: The idea that Greenland is essential to the United States has returned with a vengeance in the Trump era.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A Greenlander with his dog sled looking at the Americans’ Thule Air Base in northern Greenland in 1966.

item.title: Pushing Back on Trump, Carney Says ‘Canada Doesn’t Live Because of the United States’
item.description: The Canadian prime minister spoke after returning from the World Economic Forum where he urged middle powers to team up in resisting President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada at a news conference in Quebec City on Thursday.

item.title: RFK Jr. Plan to Test a Vaccine in West African Babies Is Blocked
item.description: A planned U.S.-funded study of a hepatitis B vaccine drew widespread condemnation from researchers. Now the host country says it cannot proceed.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen and Christina Jewett
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Each year thousands of babies born in Guinea-Bissau, one of the world’s least developed countries, are exposed to hepatitis B, a virus that can cause severe liver damage and cancer.

item.title: Davos Stops Pretending
item.description: Buzzwords like social justice and sustainability have vanished as the elite summit seeks Trump’s favor.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

item.title: An Emboldened Trump’s Whipsaw Approach to the World
item.description: He says there’s a method to the madness. But European allies wonder whether the United States is reliable anymore.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: President Trump at a reception with business leaders at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Wednesday.

item.title: Barron Trump Called U.K. Police After Witnessing Woman ‘Getting Beat Up’ on Video Call
item.description: The details of an emergency call made by President Trump’s youngest son to the London police last year emerged during a trial this week.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Barron Trump at President Trump’s inaugural parade in Washington, D.C., in January last year, days after his phone call to the London police.

item.title: How Britain’s Bases in Cyprus Could Be a Blueprint for Trump’s Greenland Deal
item.description: NATO officials signaled that an agreement with Mr. Trump on Greenland may be modeled on Britain’s Sovereign Base Areas in Cyprus. Here’s what that may mean.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: President Trump said on Wednesday that he had reached a framework for a deal on the future of Greenland with Mark Rutte, left, the NATO secretary general.

item.title: At Davos, Talk of Climate Change Retreats to the Sidelines
item.description: The annual gathering of top business leaders and policymakers used to be a center of the global climate movement. Things are much more complicated now.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:description: At the Davos forum in recent years, the focus on climate change and stopping biodiversity loss has taken a back seat to issues like cryptocurrency, artificial intelligence and geopolitics.

item.title: Venezuela’s Edmundo González Said His Son-in-Law Was Freed From Detention
item.description: Edmundo González, seen by many as the real winner of Venezuela’s 2024 election, said his son-in-law was released after more than a year in detention.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Mariana González de Tudares, right, daughter of the former Venezuelan presidential candidate Edmundo González, waiting this month outside a detention center in Caracas, Venezuela.

item.title: Zelensky Laces Into Europe, Saying It Must Step Up or Be Left Behind
item.description: The Ukrainian leader’s speech in Davos, Switzerland, was one of his most scathing critiques of his closest allies.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine delivered a blunt speech in Davos, Switzerland, on Thursday.

item.title: Denmark Bristles at Idea of Giving Up Any Sovereignty in Greenland
item.description: American and NATO officials have discussed giving the United States sovereignty over U.S. military bases in Greenland. The Danes don’t seem to like that.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman, Maya Tekeli and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Thomas Traasdahl/Ritzau Scanpix, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen of Denmark, in Copenhagen on Tuesday, released a statement saying, “Only Denmark and Greenland themselves can make decisions on issues concerning Denmark and Greenland.”

item.title: A 67,800-Year-Old Handprint May Be the World’s Oldest Rock Art
item.description: “It was hiding in plain sight all this time,” one researcher said.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses and Yan Zhuang

item.title: Trump Returns to a Familiar Role: Sowing Trade Chaos
item.description: The president’s quick reversal on tariffs over Greenland was another sign of his willingness to rip up the international order — even parts of it that he himself has made.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: President Trump on Wednesday gave a menacing speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, before backtracking on a brewing trade war with Europe.

item.title: Putin Says Russia Could Donate to ‘Board of Peace’ if U.S. Unfroze Assets
item.description: The Kremlin leader said he will discuss the possibility today with Trump administration envoys in Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at the Kremlin on Thursday.

item.title: Newsom Blames Trump for Cancellation of His Davos Appearance
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California said the Trump administration had denied him entry to an American venue at the World Economic Forum. It’s not clear if the administration was responsible.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Wednesday.

item.title: Tânia Maria Is Brazil’s Newest Film Icon
item.description: Clad in florals and puffing on a cigarette, Tânia Maria has captivated audiences with a striking, if brief, performance in “The Secret Agent,” Brazil’s latest Oscar nominee.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tânia Maria, with Wagner Moura in a scene from “The Secret Agent,” has drawn praise from international critics.

item.title: Witkoff and Kushner Will Meet With Putin for Ukraine Talks
item.description: Steve Witkoff, President Trump’s special envoy, and Jared Kushner, the president’s son-in-law, were expected in Moscow as Mr. Witkoff expressed optimism over a plan to end Russia’s war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: Steve Witkoff, President Trump’s special envoy, and Jared Kushner, Mr. Trump’s son-in-law, at Davos on Wednesday. They are expected to meet on Thursday with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

item.title: Three Dead After Shooting in Rural Australian Town
item.description: The killings happened on a day when Australians were honoring the victims of the Bondi Beach massacre, and just after gun laws were tightened.
item.dc:creator: Laura Chung
item.media:description: The Australian and Aboriginal flags at half-staff for the victims of the Bondi Beach shooting in Sydney on Thursday.

item.title: Trump’s Rift With Europe Is Clear. Europe Must Decide What to Do About It.
item.description: After President Trump aired his disdain for Europe, its leaders will gather in Brussels Thursday to take stock of what comes next.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Jeanna Smialek
item.media:description: Mark Rutte, the NATO secretary-general, meeting with President Trump in Davos, Switzerland, on Wednesday.

item.title: Rifaat al-Assad, Paramilitary Leader and ‘Butcher of Hama,’ Dies at 88
item.description: The brother and uncle of Syrian tyrants, he commanded a unit that killed up to 40,000 civilians in a 1982 uprising against his family’s rule.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Rifaat Assad in his office in Marbella, Spain, in 2005. For more than 50 years, many of them spent in cosseted exile, he was an integral part of the family that ruled Syria with an iron fist.

item.title: Trump’s ‘Board of Peace’ Would Have Global Scope but One Man in Charge
item.description: The initiative is the latest example of the president’s dismantling the post-World War II international system and building a new one, with himself at the center.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israel, Saudi Arabia and other nations have said they would join President Trump’s proposed “Board of Peace,” but France, Norway and Sweden have said no.

item.title: At Davos, a Clash Between Trump’s World and the Old World
item.description: For decades, leaders have gathered in Davos to discuss a shared economic and political future. On Wednesday, President Trump turned the forum into a bracing clash between his worldview and theirs.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: Audience members listening to President Trump’s address at Davos on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump’s Talk of Greenland ‘Deal’ Framework Draws Mixed Reactions
item.description: A lot of confusion was swirling in Denmark and Greenland after President Trump’s bombshell of a post on social media.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman, Amelia Nierenberg and Maya Tekeli
item.media:description: People walking past a large mural in Nuuk, Greenland, on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump’s Moves on Greenland
item.description: After assailing Europe in a long speech at Davos, the president said he had won an agreement on the future of the Arctic territory.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Iran’s Protests Have Been Completely Squashed, Government Says
item.description: After a crackdown that killed thousands, Iran’s prosecutor general said on Wednesday that “the sedition is over now,” vowing to punish those responsible for the protests.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A photograph taken during a tour for international news media shows a tax office that was burned during protests, on Wednesday in Tehran.

item.title: Did the U.S. Ever Own Greenland? Fact-Checking Trump’s Davos Speech.
item.description: The president gave misleading accounts of the U.S. role in Greenland’s history and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, among other claims.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Trump speaking at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Starts Moving ISIS Detainees From Syria to Iraq
item.description: The U.S. military said it had transferred 150 Islamic State detainees from northeastern Syria to Iraq and could eventually move as many as 7,000, as the Syrian government assumes control of the region from Kurdish-led forces.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward, Eric Schmitt and Erika Solomon
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Syrian government forces guarding a position near the city of Hasakah in northeastern Syria on Wednesday.

item.title: Israeli Strikes in Gaza Kill 11, Including Three Journalists
item.description: The three journalists were operating a drone near the town of Al-Zahra.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.media:description: Abdel Raouf Shaath, shown working in Rafah in 2023, was one of three journalists killed in the Gaza Strip on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Pivot in Syria Leaves an Old Ally in the Lurch
item.description: A Kurdish force that helped defeat the Islamic State is collapsing as the Trump administration turns to back the new Syrian government.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Carlotta Gall
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Riding past a destroyed Syrian Democratic Forces vehicle on a roadside on Tuesday, near Hasakah, Syria.

item.title: The New Wild Card on Travelers’ Itineraries: Uncertainty
item.description: Politics, military action and climate change have increased risk for destinations that once seemed like sure bets, forcing travelers to change how they plan.
item.dc:creator: Gabe Castro-Root

item.title: Prince Harry Gives Emotional Testimony About Effects of News Coverage
item.description: Harry said in court that reading articles about him published by Associated Newspapers, which he has accused of acting unlawfully, had been “traumatic.”
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:description: Prince Harry arriving to testify on Wednesday in London in his case against Associated Newspapers.

item.title: Rising Global Temperatures May Affect Choices for Winter Olympic Venues
item.description: Future games will need to be held at higher altitudes, and spread over multiple venues in order to adapt to a changing climate, new research suggests.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:description: Gus Schumacher, a member of the U.S. cross-country skiing team, left, competing in Planica, Slovenia, in March 2023.
